awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CO2 activation by nitrogenase Fe proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Yilin Hu from the University of California, Irvine, to investigate carbon dioxide activation by the iron protein of nitrogenase, the enzyme responsible for nitrogen fixation in microorganisms. Conversion of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide into valuable chemicals represents an effective strategy to simultaneously combat the problems of increased carbon dioxide emission into the atmosphere and the decreased supply of fossil fuels. However, activation or splitting of carbon dioxide normally requires high temperature and pressure conditions, which puts a tremendous burden on our energy supply and environmental wellness. This pursuit focuses on just how the reaction takes place by a simple iron-sulfur enzyme, which will provide a crucial framework for future adaptations of this novel type of reaction for recycling the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide into useful products. As such, it has broad scientific impacts on our society by addressing two of the most important challenges we face nowadays: fossil fuel depletion and climate change. In addition, incorporation of this research into training of current students and outreach to prospective students raises public interest and awareness of the importance of this line of research and, therefore, has broader impacts on the education of future generations.

This project investigates the mechanism of in vitro carbon dioxide activation by the iron protein of nitrogenase and the engineering of an Azotobacter vinelandii strain with improved efficiency of in vivo carbon dioxide reduction upon expression of the iron protein. Guided by theoretical calculations, the proposed research employs a combination of genetic, biochemical, spectroscopic and structural approaches to tackle the unique reaction of carbon dioxide reduction by the all-ferrous iron protein and address several fundamental questions related to the mechanism of this reaction. Further, a combination of screening and expression strategies are used to identify iron proteins or homologs with higher efficiencies of carbon dioxide reduction and improve the specificity of electron transfer to the iron protein during the process of carbon dioxide reduction. The outcome of these studies provides important insights into how iron-sulfur based catalysts work to effect carbon dioxide activation and reduction under ambient conditions and what principles can be derived from studies of A. vinelandii for future development of cost-efficient, whole-cell-based strategies for carbon dioxide conversion.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: Conversion of the greenhouse gas CO2 into valuable chemicals represents an effective strategy to simultaneously combat the problems of increased CO2 emission into the atmosphere and decreased supply of fossil fuels. However, activation/splitting of CO2 normally requires high temperature/pressure conditions, which puts a tremendous burden on our energy supply and environmental wellness. Previously, we discovered the ability of the Fe protein component of nitrogenase to activate/reduce CO2 to CO at ambient temperature/pressure either as a purified protein in in vitro assays, or upon expression in an Azotobacter vinelandii strain under in vivo conditions. Our studies throughout the funding period of this project were based on these discoveries, and we have made substantial progress toward understanding the mechanism of CO2 activation by Fe protein and engineering bacterial strains to overexpress Fe protein and sustain in vivo CO2 reduction. Together, the outcome of our studies provides important insights into how a simple FeS-based biocatalyst works to effect the activation and reduction of CO2 under ambient conditions and what principles can be derived from this model system to develop cost-efficient, whole-cell-based strategies for CO2 conversion in the future.

Intellectual Merit: This proposal was based on our previous findings that the nitrogenase Fe protein can effect both in vitro and in vivo conversion of CO2 to CO under ambient conditions, which established this protein as a novel, simple FeS model system for mechanistic investigations of ambient CO2 activation/reduction while suggesting the utility of organisms that overexpress nitrogenase Fe proteins/homologs in developing strategies to improve the efficiency of whole-cell-based CO2 conversion. This project employs an effective combination of genetic, biochemical, spectroscopic, structural, and theoretical approaches to tackle the reaction of CO2 reduction by the all-ferrous Fe protein and address the fundamental questions related to the mechanism of this important reaction. Moreover, it utilizes a unique combination of screening and expression strategies to identify and overproduce Fe proteins/homologs with improved specificity in electron transfer and elevated efficiency in CO2 reduction. Collectively, these studies contribute to the establishment of an important framework for the future adaptations of this novel reaction to ambient conversion of CO2 into useful products. 

Broader Impacts: The broader scientific impacts of the proposed work can be appreciated from the perspective of the dual function of CO2 conversion that simultaneously reduces the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere and recycles this greenhouse gas into useful products, both of which are of inherent importance to our society. Our exciting discovery that the nitrogenase Fe protein can convert CO2 to one of the major syngas components, CO, under ambient conditions defines a novel function of the nitrogenase system. This project tackles the mechanism of the activation and conversion of CO2 by Fe protein, which is crucial for the future biotechnological adaptations/applications of this novel reaction and, in the long run, could address two most important challenges for our society: energy depletion and global warming. In addition to its scientific impact, our research has broader impacts through outreach efforts, such as Science Saturdays at UC Irvine, which has been hosted by our labs throughout the entire period of this project. Aiming to serve the local SoCal community, Science Saturdays at UC Irvine brings local middle school students to biology and chemistry labs on campus at UCI. Our main goal is to broaden the understanding of science and technology among minorities and the underprivileged kids and to increase their participation in scientific study. The program has been designed by us using NSF guidelines and is headed by our graduate students. Ten events have been completed to date, each with approximately fifty students visiting from Julia Lathrop Intermediate School (JLIS) and Carr Intermediate School (CIS) of the Santa Ana Unified School District. Over 90% of the student population of the Santa Ana Unified School District are Latino/Hispanic, with most of them being first-generation Americans and 95% receiving state-mandated free lunches due to low family income. The students and teachers at JLIS and CIS are particularly interested in this experience because their schools have limited facilities for scientific experimentation, and science classes are often taught with no laboratory component. The overwhelmingly positive comments from the visiting students highlight the positive impact of our outreach efforts on motivating young students, particularly the minority and underprivileged students from the SoCal community, to pursue STEM careers in the future.
